lines.text: Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Tis one of the best discretions of a oman as ever I did look upon.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: And did he send you both these letters at an instant

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Within a quarter of an hour.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Pardon me, wife. Henceforth do what thou wilt I rather will suspect the sun with cold Than thee with wantonness: now doth thy honour stand In him that was of late an heretic, As firm as faith.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Tis well, tis well no more: Be not as extreme in submission As in offence. But let our plot go forward: let our wives Yet once again, to make us public sport, Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow, Where we may take him and disgrace him for it.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: How to send him word theyll meet him in the park at midnight Fie, fie! hell never come.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: You say he has been thrown in the rivers and has been grievously peaten as an old oman: methinks there should be terrors in him that he should not come methinks his flesh is punished, he shall have no desires.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: So think I too.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Devise but how youll use him when he comes, And let us two devise to bring him thither.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: There is an old tale goes that Herne the hunter, Sometime a keeper here in Windsor forest, Doth all the wintertime, at still midnight, Walk round about an oak, with great raggd horns And there he blasts the tree and takes the cattle And makes milchkine yield blood and shakes a chain In a most hideous and dreadful manner: You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know The superstitious idleheaded eld Received and did deliver to our age This tale of Herne the hunter for a truth.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Why, yet there want not many that do fear In deep of night to walk by this Hernes oak: But what of this

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Marry, this is our device That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Well, let it not be doubted but hell come: And in this shape when you have brought him thither, What shall be done with him what is your plot

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus: Nan Page my daughter and my little son And three or four more of their growth well dress Like urchins, ouphes and fairies, green and white, With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads, And rattles in their hands: upon a sudden, As Falstaff, she and I, are newly met, Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once With some diffused song: upon their sight, We two in great amazedness will fly: Then let them all encircle him about And, fairylike, topinch the unclean knight, And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel, In their so sacred paths he dares to tread In shape profane.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: And till he tell the truth, Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound And burn him with their tapers.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: The truth being known, Well all present ourselves, dishorn the spirit, And mock him home to Windsor.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: The children must Be practised well to this, or theyll neer dot.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: I will teach the children their behaviors and I will be like a jackanapes also, to burn the knight with my taber.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: That will be excellent. Ill go and buy them vizards.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: My Nan shall be the queen of all the fairies, Finely attired in a robe of white.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: That silk will I go buy. And in that time Shall Master Slender steal my Nan away And marry her at Eton. Go send to Falstaff straight.
Aside

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Nay Ill to him again in name of Brook Hell tell me all his purpose: sure, hell come.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Fear not you that. Go get us properties And tricking for our fairies.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Let us about it: it is admirable pleasures and fery honest knaveries.
Exeunt PAGE, FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Go, Mistress Ford, Send quickly to Sir John, to know his mind. Ill to the doctor: he hath my good will, And none but he, to marry with Nan Page. That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot And he my husband best of all affects. The doctor is well moneyd, and his friends Potent at court: he, none but he, shall have her, Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her.
Exit MISTRESS FORD
Exit
